subject: Macrophage migration inhibitory factor
Text: Macrophage migration inhibitory factor is critical for dengue NS1-induced endothelial glycocalyx degradation and hyperpermeability

subject: MIF
Text: MIF in DENV NS1-induced endothelial glycocalyx degradation and hyperpermeability

subject: NS1
Text: Nonstructural protein 1 (NS1) of dengue virus (DENV) can stimulate endothelial cells to secrete endothelial hyperpermeability factor, macrophage migration inhibitory factor (MIF), and the glycocalyx degradation factor heparanase 1 (HPA-1).

subject: MIF
Text: However, it is unclear whether MIF is directly involved in NS1-induced glycocalyx degradation.

Text: only NS1 and MIF showed a positive correlation with the CD138 level in severe patients.

subject: NS1
Text: Our tabulated results suggested that NS1 stimulation could induce human endothelial cells to secrete HPA-1 and immune cells to secrete MMP-9, resulting in endothelial glycocalyx degradation and hyperpermeability.

subject: NS1 stimulation
Text: Moreover, HPA-1, MMP-9, and CD138 secretion after NS1 stimulation was blocked by MIF inhibitors or antibodies both in vitro and in mice.

subject: MIF
Text: Taken together, these results suggest that MIF directly engages in dengue NS1-induced glycocalyx degradation.

subject: endothelial glycocalyx
Text: Shedding of the endothelial glycocalyx is related to the activation of a heparan sulfate-specific heparanase, HPA-1.

subject: HPA-1
Text: Activated HPA-1 enhances shedding of the transmembrane heparan sulfate proteoglycan syndecan-1 (CD138) and elevates the level of CD138 in the bloodstream.

subject: matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs)
Text: In addition, matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) are capable of digesting many types of extracellular matrix, including the endothelial glycocalyx.

subject: DENV nonstructural protein 1 (NS1)
Text: In addition, NS1 can induce the expression and activation of HPA-1, leading to endothelial glycocalyx degradation and hyperpermeability.

subject: DENV nonstructural protein 1 (NS1)
Text: In our previous study, we found that DENV NS1 can increase vascular permeability through macrophage migration inhibitory factor (MIF)-induced autophagy.

subject: MIF
Text: MIF is a chemokine-like inflammatory cytokine that binds to cell surface receptors (CD74 and/or CXCR2/4/7) and activates downstream signals, such as MAPK/ERK, to modulate inflammatory and immune responses.

subject: DENV infection
Text: DENV infection can induce MIF secretion.

subject: DENV infection-induced disease
Text: DENV infection-induced disease was found to be less severe in MIF knockout (Mif-/-) mice than in normal mice.

subject: NS1
Text: However, it is unclear whether MIF is directly involved in NS1-induced glycocalyx degradation.

subject: NS1
Text: Most importantly, the NS1-induced increases in HPA-1, MMP-9, and CD138 were all inhibited in the presence of MIF inhibitors or antibodies both in vitro and in vivo, indicating that NS1-induced MIF secretion may play an important role in the pathogenesis of DENV NS1-induced glycocalyx degradation and vascular leakage.

subject: NS1
Text: DENV NS1-induced endothelial HPA-1 secretion leads to glycocalyx degradation and hyperpermeability and is MIF dependent

subject: NS1
Text: According to a previous study, NS1 can induce endothelial cells to secrete HPA-1 to disrupt the endothelial glycocalyx, and this disruption is characterized by CD138 shedding

subject: NS1
Text: (A) HUVECs were treated with PBS or 20 μg/ml NS1 recombinant proteins for the indicated time, followed by collection of the supernatants for CD138 detection by ELISA. (n = 4)

subject: NS1
Text: (B) HUVECs were treated with PBS, 20 μg/ml NS1, or 20 μg/ml NS1 mixed with 10 μg/ml anti-NS1 antibodies (2E8 or DN5C6). After 24 h of incubation, the culture medium was collected, and the concentration of CD138 was determined by ELISA. (n = 3)

subject: NS1
Text: (C) HUVECs seeded as monolayers in upper Transwell chambers were treated with PBS, 20 μg/ml NS1 or 20 μg/ml NS1 mixed with DMSO or the indicated concentration of OGT 2115. After 24 h, endothelial permeability was determined by a Transwell permeability assay, as described in the Materials and Methods section. (n = 3)

subject: NS1
Text: (D) HUVECs were treated with PBS or 20 μg/ml NS1 with or without 5 μM OGT 2115. After 24 h, the cell culture medium was collected, and the CD138 concentration was measured by ELISA. (n = 5)

subject: NS1
Text: (E) HUVECs were treated with PBS or 20 μg/ml NS1 with or without 100 μM p425, 50 μM ISO-1, or 10 μg/ml anti-MIF antibodies, as indicated. After 24 h, the cell culture medium was collected, and the HPA-1 concentration was measured by ELISA. (n = 3)

subject: NS1
Text: (F) HUVECs were treated with PBS or 20 μg/ml NS1 with or without p425, ISO-1 or anti-MIF antibodies. After 24 h, the cell culture medium was collected, and the CD138 concentration was measured by ELISA. (n = 5)

subject: NS1
Text: (G) HUVECs were treated with PBS or NS1 (20 μg/ml) with or without anti-MIF polyclonal antibodies (10 μg/ml) for 24 h. The distribution of HPA-1 (red) and CD138 (green) was assessed by staining with specific antibodies. Sialic acid expression on HUVECs monolayers was assessed by staining with WGA-FITC (green). *P<0.05, **P<0.01, ***P<0.001; ns, not significant; unpaired t-test (panel A), Kruskal-Wallis ANOVA (panel B, C, D, E and F).

subject: MIF
Text: In addition to HPA-1, MIF is also capable of inducing endothelial hyperpermeability [19].

subject: NS1
Text: As a result, the MIF concentration in the conditioned medium obtained from NS1-stimulated HUVECs was measured.

subject: NS1-stimulated HUVECs
Text: The result shows that 10 μg/ml NS1 was sufficient to induce MIF secretion.

subject: NS1-stimulated HUVECs
Text: Furthermore, the conditioned medium obtained from NS1-stimulated HUVECs could induce endothelial hyperpermeability.

subject: NS1-stimulated HUVECs
Text: Furthermore, the conditioned medium obtained from NS1-stimulated HUVECs could induce CD138 shedding after incubation with another HUVEC monolayer.

subject: MIF-blocking antibodies, the HPA-1 inhibitor OGT 2115, NS1-blocking antibodies
object: NS1-stimulated conditioned medium-induced HUVEC hyperpermeability and CD138 shedding
Text: The results show that both the anti-MIF antibodies and OGT 2115 attenuated NS1-stimulated conditioned medium-induced HUVEC hyperpermeability and CD138 shedding.

subject: NS1-blocking antibody 2E8
Text: Interestingly, the NS1-blocking antibody 2E8 only partially diminished the conditioned medium-induced HUVEC hyperpermeability.

subject: MIF inhibitors (anti-MIF antibodies, ISO-1, and p425), NS1
object: NS1-induced HPA-1 secretion and CD138 shedding of endothelial cells
Text: Cotreatment with MIF inhibitors (anti-MIF antibodies, ISO-1, and p425) and NS1 also attenuated the NS1-induced HPA-1 secretion and CD138 shedding of endothelial cells.

subject: MIF inhibition
object: NS1-induced HPA-1 expression, CD138 deposition, and sialic acid degradation
Text: NS1-induced HPA-1 expression, CD138 deposition, and sialic acid degradation could also be rescued by MIF inhibition.

subject: MIF
Text: However, the HPA-1 inhibitor OGT 2115 failed to affect MIF secretion, suggested that MIF is the upstream effector of HPA-1.

subject: recombinant MIF
object: CD138 shedding and active HPA-1 level in HUVECs
Text: The results show that MIF increased CD138 shedding and the active HPA-1 level in HUVECs.

subject: MIF stimulation
Text: The increased HPA-1 expression and CD138 deposition after MIF stimulation could also be observed by immunofluorescence.

subject: NS1
Text: DENV NS1 induces MMP-9 secretion in THP-1 cells and leukocytes.

subject: MMPs
Text: Since MMPs can degrade the endothelial glycocalyx and several MMPs are upregulated during DENV infection [30, 31], we speculated that MMPs are involved in NS1-induced glycocalyx degradation.

subject: MMPs
Text: we first examined whether NS1 induces MMP-9 secretion. However, we found that NS1 barely induced MMP-9 secretion in HUVECs.

subject: MMPs
Text: we tested whether NS1 could induce MMP secretion in human leukocytes, peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs), and THP-1 human monocytes.

subject: NS1
Text: we found that NS1 induced MMP-9 secretion in freshly isolated leukocytes after 3 h of stimulation.

subject: NS1
Text: Similarly, NS1 induced phorbol myristate acetate (PMA)-activated THP-1 cells to secrete MMP-9 after incubation for 3 h.

subject: NS1
Text: NS1 induces MMP-9 secretion from human leukocytes but not HUVECs.

subject: NS1
Text: NS1 induced MMP-9 secretion in freshly isolated leukocytes after 3 h of stimulation.

subject: NS1
Text: Similarly, NS1 induced phorbol myristate acetate (PMA)-activated THP-1 cells to secrete MMP-9 after incubation for 3 h.

subject: NS1
Text: DENV NS1-induced MMP-9 secretion from THP-1 cells increases endothelial permeability and glycocalyx degradation.

subject: NS1
Text: To test whether the NS1-induced MMP-9 secretion of THP-1 cells causes endothelial hyperpermeability, the supernatant from NS1-treated THP-1 cells was incubated with HUVECs, and both permeability and CD138 shedding were examined.

subject: NS1
Text: The results show that after 3 h of treatment, the supernatant from NS1-treated THP-1 cells increased endothelial permeability. This phenomenon was attenuated in the presence of the MMP-2/MMP-9 inhibitor SB-3CT and the MMP-9-specific inhibitor MMP-9 inhibitor I.

subject: NS1
Text: Similarly, the supernatant from NS1-treated THP-1 cells also induced CD138 shedding from HUVECs, and this effect was diminished by SB-3CT and MMP-9 inhibitor I.

subject: NS1
Text: MIF is required for DENV NS1-induced MMP-9 secretion. As MIF is a crucial mediator of NS1-induced vascular leakage and an upstream regulator of MMP-9, we tested whether NS1-induced MMP-9 secretion in leukocytes is also MIF dependent.

subject: NS1
Text: To clarify whether NS1-induced MMP-9 secretion is mediated by MIF, the MIF inhibitor p425 and MIF short-hairpin RNA (shRNA) were used.

subject: MIF
Text: NS1-induced MMP-9 secretion from THP-1 cells is regulated by MIF.

subject: MIF
Text: DENV NS1 induces MIF, HPA-1, MMP-9 and CD138 secretion in mice.

subject: MIF
Text: These results suggest that MIF acts on both endothelial cells and leukocytes to mediate NS1-induced endothelial hyperpermeability.

subject: MIF
Text: MIF inhibition attenuates DENV NS1-induced glycocalyx degradation in mice.

subject: NS1
Text: Nonstructural protein 1 (NS1) of dengue virus (DENV) can stimulate endothelial cells to secrete endothelial hyperpermeability factor, macrophage migration inhibitory factor (MIF), and the glycocalyx degradation factor heparanase 1 (HPA-1).

Text: Nonstructural protein 1 (NS1) of dengue virus (DENV) can stimulate endothelial cells to secrete endothelial hyperpermeability factor, macrophage migration inhibitory factor (MIF), and the glycocalyx degradation factor heparanase 1 (HPA-1).

Text: Next, we showed that the DENV NS1 stimulation of endothelial cells and leukocytes could induce HPA-1 and MMP-9 secretion, respectively, causing endothelial glycocalyx degradation and hyperpermeability.

subject: MIF
Text: In this study, we first observed that the concentrations of NS1, MIF, HPA-1, MMP-9 and CD138 in the serum of dengue patients were increased. However, only the concentrations of NS1 and MIF showed a positive correlation with CD138 in severe dengue patients.

subject: NS1
Text: Most importantly, both in vitro and in vivo data showed that dengue NS1-induced HPA-1 and MMP-9 secretion was MIF dependent.

Text: Most importantly, both in vitro and in vivo data showed that dengue NS1-induced HPA-1 and MMP-9 secretion was MIF dependent.

subject: HPA-1
Text: Previously, Puerta-Guardo et al. showed that HPA-1 is involved in NS1-induced glycocalyx degradation and hyperpermeability [18].

subject: MMP-9
Text: However, MMPs were not discussed in the mechanism, even though they are the main enzymes that degrade endothelial glycocalyx [11, 12].

subject: DENV infection
Text: It is known that DENV infection induces dendritic cells to secrete MMP-9 [31].

subject: NS1
Text: In this study, we further demonstrated that the NS1 stimulation of leukocytes but not endothelial cells nor PBMCs could induce MMP-9 secretion.

subject: DENV NS1
Text: It is known that DENV NS1 can induce neutrophil extracellular traps, which results in the release of tertiary granules containing MMP-9 [37, 38].

subject: MIF
Text: A previous study has also shown that MIF can mediate the secretion of MMP-9 from neutrophils [39].

subject: NS1
Text: Since neutrophils are a major population of leukocytes, taken together, these results suggest that NS1-stimulated neutrophils may represent the main contributors to MMP-9 secretion in the blood.

subject: MMP-9
Text: Interestingly, although it has been shown in previous studies that the concentrations of MMPs are increased in dengue patients [13, 32] and MMP-9 upregulation is positively correlated with the disease severity and vascular leakage of dengue [31, 32, 42, 43], we observed a significant increase in the serum level of MMP-9 only in dengue patients with warning signs, not in severe dengue patients.

subject: NS1
Text: From the in vivo mouse study, we noticed that the secretion of MMP-9 occurred within a smaller time window than that of HPA-1 in mice after NS1 challenge.

subject: TIMP-1
Text: TIMP-1, which is a potent inhibitor of MMPs, can form a complex with pro-MMP-9 at a 1:1 stoichiometric relationship to inhibit its activation [44, 45].

Text: As NS1 needs at least 24 h to induce endothelial glycocalyx degradation (Fig 3A), we speculated that IL-6 and IL-8 are not very involved in NS1-induced endothelial glycocalyx degradation.

Text: In addition, we further demonstrated that both the secretion of HPA-1 and the shedding of CD138 induced by NS1-stimulation of endothelial cells are mediated by MIF.

Text: Due to MIF regulating the secretion of both MMP-9 and HPA-1 and because CD138 shedding was also directly affected by MIF signaling, MIF may be an upstream regulator of DENV NS1-induced glycocalyx degradation.

Text: DENV NS1 may bind to the TLR4 of leukocytes, inducing the secretion of cytokines and MMPs, or it may directly bind to endothelial cells, inducing the secretion of HPA-1, both of which can cause glycocalyx degradation and subsequent vascular leakage.

Text: MIF is also known to activate NF-κB signaling through binding to CD74 [49].

subject: DENV infection
Text: The aim of this study was to clarify the mechanism of DENV infection-induced endothelial glycocalyx degradation.

subject: clinical samples
Text: From analyzing clinical samples, we correlated glycocalyx degradation to MIF secretion.

subject: MIF
Text: By applying the results from other studies, we hypothesized that HPA-1 or MMP-9 was involved in MIF-mediated glycocalyx degradation in dengue.

subject: NS1
Text: This hypothesis was examined via in vitro experiments, which were carried out by recombinant NS1 stimulation, as it was indicated as an important effector in severe dengue.

subject: NS1
Text: Since the interaction between different cell types is critical under physiological conditions, we assessed the DENV NS1-induced effects on both endothelial cells and leukocytes.

subject: MMPs
Text: To further elucidate the involvement of MMPs in this mechanism, MMP antibody array and gelatin zymography assays were performed.

subject: NS1
Text: Subsequently, recombinant NS1 was injected into mice systemically or locally to confirm the involvement of MIF, HPA-1 and MMP-9 in NS1-induced endothelial glycocalyx degradation and hyperpermeability in vivo.

subject: NS1
Text: To inhibit MIF activity, HUVECs were cotreated for 24 h with NS1 and either 100 μM p425 (6,6ʹ-[(3,3-dimethoxy[1,1ʹ-biphenyl]-4,4ʹ-diyl)bis(azo)]bis[4-amino-5-hydroxy-1,3-napthalenedisulphonic acid] tetrasodium salt; Calbiochem, La Jolla, CA, USA) or 50 μM ISO-1 ((S,R)-3-(4-hydroxyphenyl)-4,5-dihydro-5-isoxazole acetic acid; Calbiochem).

subject: NS1
Text: To inhibit HPA-1, OGT 2115 (Tocris Bioscience, Bristol, UK) was used at the indicated concentration.

subject: NS1
Text: To inhibit MMP-9, SB-3CT (Abcam, Cambridge, UK) and MMP-9 inhibitor I (Santa Cruz, Dallas, TX, USA) were used at the indicated concentrations.

subject: NS1
Text: A Transwell permeability assay was performed as described in a previous study [58]. HUVECs (2 x 105) were grown on a Transwell insert (0.4 μm; Corning Life Sciences, Corning, NY, USA) until a monolayer formed. The upper chambers were reconstituted with 20 μg/ml NS1, culture supernatant from NS1-activated THP-1 cells, or the inhibitor-containing medium.

subject: NS1
Text: To measure the integrity of the endothelial glycocalyx and the deposition of CD138, the expression of sialic acid was stained with wheat germ agglutinin (WGA) lectin conjugated to FITC (WGA-FITC, Genetex) and the distribution of HPA-1 and CD138 was detected by anti-mouse-CD138 mAb (BD, Franklin Lakes, NJ, USA) or rabbit anti-HPA-1 polyclonal antibody (GeneTex).

subject: NS1
Text: The human MMP antibody array (Abcam) was used according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Briefly, array membranes were incubated in equal quantities of the culture supernatant from PBS- or NS1-treated THP-1 cells or NS1-treated leukocytes for 24 h overnight at 4°C.

subject: NS1
Text: MMP activity in the culture supernatant was assayed by gelatin zymography using 7.5% acrylamide gel containing gelatin [59]. Briefly, the culture supernatant of NS1-treated THP-1 cells or leukocytes was concentrated.
